					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate" >GRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Graduate Alumni                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-586021" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	Students who have received a PhD or AM in Comparative Literature have gone on to careers in a variety of fields, in both academic and non-academic roles. Past graduate alumni include:
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Marie Louise Ascher</strong>, PhD 1997, Senior Editor, Harvard University Press; freelance translator
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://complit.cornell.edu/andrea-bachner" title="">Andrea Bachner</a></strong>, PhD 2007, Assistant Professor of Comparative Literature, Cornell University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://ritabanerjee.com/">Rita Banerjee</a></strong>, PhD 2013, Lecturer in the Institute for Indology and Tibetology, Ludwig-Maximilians-Universität München; Executive Creative Director, Cambridge Writers' Workshop, Inc. 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Susan Barba</strong>, PhD 2006, Senior Editor, New York Review of Books
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Bruce A. Beatie</strong>, PhD 1967, Professor Emeritus of Classics and Comparative Literature, Cleveland State University
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pub/steve-berrien/3b/26b/a56">Steve Berrien</a></strong>, PhD 1989, Vice Chancellor of Academic Affairs, Fletcher Technical Community College 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Guillermo Bleichmar</strong>, PhD 2007, Professor of Liberal Arts, St. John’s College Santa Fe
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.northeastern.edu/cssh/faculty/erika-boeckeler" title="">Erika Boeckeler</a></strong>, PhD 2007, Assistant Professor of English, Northeastern University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Carmelita Boivin-Cole</strong>, PhD 1982, Consultant; formerly Chief Executive Officer of the Maritime Provinces Higher Education Commission, Nova Scotia and Director General of Atlantic Canada Economic Development Agency
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://tulane.edu/liberal-arts/german-slavic-studies/elio-brancaforte.cfm">Elio Brancaforte</a></strong>, PhD 2001, Associate Professor of German, Tulane University
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://complit.yale.edu/people/peter-brooks">Peter Brooks</a></strong>, PhD 1965, Sterling Professor Emeritus of Comparative Literature at Yale University, Andrew W. Mellon Foundation Scholar in the University Center for Human Values and the Department of Comparative Literature at Princeton University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://revivingcreation.org/" title="">Margaret Bullitt-Jonas</a></strong>, PhD 1984, Missioner for Creation Care at Episcopal Diocese of Western Massachusetts 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://watson.brown.edu/mes/people/vangelis-calotychos" title="">Vangelis Calotychos</a></strong>, PhD 1993, Visiting Associate Professor of Comparative Literature, Brown University
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.wsgr.com/WSGR/DBIndex.aspx?SectionName=attorneys/BIOS/1953.htm">Lisa Davis</a></strong>, PhD 1991, Counsel, Wilson Sonsini Goodrich &amp; Rosati 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Siegfried (Sizzo) de Rachewiltz</strong>, PhD 1983, Director, Brunnenburg Agricultural Museum and International Study Center
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://english.okstate.edu/faculty/11-faculty/20-randi-eldevik">Randi Eldevik</a></strong>, PhD 1987, Associate Professor in Department of English, Oklahoma State University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://andersengbergpedersen.wordpress.com/">Anders Engberg-Pedersen</a></strong>, PhD 2012, Associate Professor of Comparative Literature, University of Southern Denmark 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.lesley.edu/about/faculty-staff-directory/christine-evans" title="">Christine Evans</a></strong>, PhD 1985, Professor of Comparative Literature and Humanities Division Director, Lesley University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://lit.mit.edu/people/sframpton/">Stephanie Frampton</a></strong>, PhD 2011, Assistant Professor of Classical Literature, Massachusetts Institute of Technology 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://ling.yale.edu/people/roberta-frank">Roberta Frank</a></strong>, PhD 1968, Marie Borroff Professor of English and Linguistics, Yale University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Brian Gilbert Freeman</strong>, PhD 2003, English Department Chair, Brunswick School, Greenwich, Connecticut
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://raphaelgolbtrial.wordpress.com/">Raphael Golb</a></strong>, PhD 1996, Internet troll  
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://volvement.blogspot.com/">Jeffrey M.Green</a></strong>, PhD 1973, Freelance translator, editor &amp; writer  
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://umaine.edu/las/deans-office/ ">Emily Haddad</a></strong>, PhD 1997, Dean of College of Liberal Arts and Sciences at the University of Maine 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pub/john-hamilton/b/2b/7b0">John Hamilton</a></strong>, PhD 1979, Business Development Executive at AT&amp;T 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://isearch.asu.edu/profile/2876775" title="">Ana Hedberg Olenina</a></strong>, PhD 2012, Assistant Professor of Comparative Literature and Media Studies at Arizona State University
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://darahorn.com/">Dara Horn</a></strong>, PhD 2006, Novelist; Literary Critic; Gerald Weinstock Visiting Lecturer in Jewish Studies, Harvard University (Fall 2014) 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.michelejaffe.com/">Michele Jaffe</a></strong>, PhD 1998, Novelist 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Seung Hee Jeon</strong>, PhD 2005, Research Professor at Yonsei University; Senior Editor at Asia Publishers; freelance writer, editor and translator
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.koheneducationalservices.com">Robert Kohen</a></strong>, PhD 2014, Owner, Kohen Educational Services 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.islamicstudies.harvard.edu/faculty/luke-a-leafgren/">Luke Leafgren</a></strong>, PhD 2012, Assistant Dean of Harvard College, Mather House; freelance translator 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://nyu.academia.edu/AnneLounsbery" title="">Anne Lounsbery</a></strong>, PhD 1999, Associate Professor of Russian Literature, New York University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.spanport.ucsb.edu/people/juan-pablo-lupi">Juan Pablo Lupi</a></strong>, PhD 2005, Associate Professor in the Department of Spanish and Portuguese, University of California Santa Barbara 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://italian.rutgers.edu/faculty-132/faculty/marsh-david">David Marsh</a></strong>, PhD 1978, Professor of Italian, Rutgers University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.ici-berlin.org/profile/masnatta/">Clara Masnatta</a></strong>, PhD 2012, Postdoctoral Fellow, ICI Berlin Institute for Cultural Inquiry 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Irving Massey</strong>, PhD 1954, Professor of English and Comparative Literature Emeritus, State University of New York at Buffalo
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.hws.edu/academics/wrrh/facultyProfile.aspx?facultyID=653">Margueritte Murphy</a></strong>, PhD 1985, Chair, Writing &amp; Rhetoric Program, Hobart and William Smith Colleges 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.winstonchurchillfoundation.org" title="">Peter C. Patrikis</a></strong>, PhD 1976, Former Executive Director Winston Churchill Foundation
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.roxanapopescu.com/">Roxana Popescu</a></strong>, PhD 2010, Freelance reporter, blogger; Senior Reporter for Union-Tribune newspaper 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.law.washington.edu/Directory/Profile.aspx?ID=602">Zahr Said</a></strong>, PhD 2003, Assistant Professor of Law, University of Washington School of Law 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.hood.edu/Academics/Departments/English/Faculty/Mark-Sandona.html">Mark Sandona</a></strong>, PhD 1989, Professor of English, Hood College 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://dramadance.tufts.edu/people/senelick.htm">Laurence Senelick</a></strong>, PhD 1972, Fletcher Professor of Oratory; Director of Graduate Studies in Drama, Tufts University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Jerome E. Singerman</strong>, PhD 1981, Acquisitions Editor (Senior Humanities Editor), University of Pennsylvania Press
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/david-stern">David Stern</a></strong>, PhD 1980, David Starr of Classical and Modern Jewish and Hebrew Literature and Professor of Comparative Literature, Harvard University.
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://english.columbia.edu/people/profile/453">Dennis Tenen</a></strong>, PhD 2012, Assistant Professor, Department of English and Comparative Literature, Columbia University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.faculty.umb.edu/brian_thompson/home.htm">Brian Thompson</a></strong>, PhD 1970, Professor of French Emeritus, University of Massachusetts Boston 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://directory.salemstate.edu/profile/keja.valens" title="">Keja Valens</a></strong>, PhD 2004, Associate Professor of English, Salem State University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.bard.edu/academics/faculty/faculty.php?id=904">Marina van Zuylen</a></strong>, PhD 1990, Professor of French and Comparative Literature; Director, French Studies Program, Bard College 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://complit.rutgers.edu/people/faculty-mainmenu/86-people/faculty-personal-pages/139-janet-a-walker">Janet A. Walker</a></strong>, PhD 1975, Professor of Comparative Literature, Rutgers University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://complit.rutgers.edu/component/content/article?id=161:steven-f-walker">Steven F. Walker</a></strong>, PhD 1973, Professor of Comparative Literature, Rutgers University 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/pub/robert-h-waugh/90/451/b64">Robert H. Waugh</a></strong>, PhD 1972, Professor Emeritus at SUNY New Paltz
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://complitforlang.ucr.edu/people/faculty/bio.html?page=ye.html">Yang Ye</a></strong>, PhD 1989, Associate Professor of Comparative Literature, University of California Riverside 
</p>

<p>
	<strong><a href="http://www.haverford.edu/religion/faculty/tzadeh/homepage/Bio.html">Travis Zadeh</a></strong>, PhD 2007, Assistant Professor in Department of Religious Studies, Yale University
</p>

<p>
	<br />Follow us via the <strong><a href="https://www.facebook.com/harvardcomplit">Comp Lit Department page</a> </strong>on Facebook<strong>!</strong>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-38531"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate"  class="active-trail active">Graduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42881"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admissions" >Admissions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42891"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/forms-and-resources" >Forms and Resources</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-131331"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/journalsconferences-graduate-students" >Journals/Conferences for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42886"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/guide-graduate-students" >Guide for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-45931"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-dissertations" >PhD Dissertations</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42896"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/poggioli-colloquium" >Poggioli Faculty/Student Colloquium</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48421"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/teaching" >Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-106121"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-alumni"  class="active-trail active active">Graduate Alumni</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-108431"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/alumni-connect" >Alumni Directory </a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-146616"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-field-comparative-literature" >Secondary Field in Comparative Literature</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1443549664" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1443549664"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

  <div class="content">

href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/17146" >People</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-12716 </a></li><li class="menu-12721 menuparent  menu-path-complitfasharvardedu-people-role-faculty   even  "><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/role/faculty" >Faculty</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-13339 menu-path-node-729431  first   odd   last "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faculty-books" >Books by Our Faculty</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-12723 menu-path-complitfasharvardedu-people-role-graduate-students   odd  "><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/role/graduate-students" >Graduate Students</a></li><li class="menu-12727 menu-path-complitfasharvardedu-people-role-tutorial-board   even  "><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/role/tutorial-board" >Undergraduate Tutorial Board</a></li><li class="menu-12718 menu-path-complitfasharvardedu-people-role-emeritus-faculty   odd  "><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/role/emeritus-faculty"  title="">Emeriti / Emeritae Faculty</a></li><li class="menu-12729 menu-path-complitfasharvardedu-people-role-visiting-scholar   even   last "><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/role/visiting-scholar"  title="">Visiting Scholars</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-3472 menu-path-node-92666   even  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/news-events"  title="">News</a></li><li class="menu-3814 menuparent  menu-path-node-105801   odd  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/resources"  title="">Resources</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-4406 menu-path-node-114731  first   odd  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/publications" >Publications</a></li><li class="menu-12979 menu-path-complitfasharvardedu-publication-subsidies   even  "><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/publication-subsidies" >Publication Subsidies </a></li><li class="menu-4407 menu-path-node-127646   odd  "><a   </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate" >GRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Journals/Conferences for Graduate Students                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-776936" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p style="text-align:left">Suggestions from Comparative Literature Faculty and Students for Places to Present and Publish Your Work (suggestions welcome – this list is currently under construction)</p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>CLASSICS<br /><br /></strong>Journals: <a href="https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/transactions_of_the_american_philological_association/">TAPA</a> (Transactions of the American Philological Association) /<a href="https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/arethusa/">Arethusa</a> /<a href="http:/www.journals.aiac.org.au/index.php/IJCLTS">International</a></p>
<p><a href="http://www.springer.com/new+%26+forthcoming+titles+(default)/journal/12138">Journal of the Classical Tradition /</a><a href="http://chs.harvard.edu/CHS/article/display/1167">Classics@</a><a href="http://www.springer.com/new+%26+forthcoming+titles+(default)/journal/12138"></a> (the Center for Hellenic Studies’ on-line journal)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Conference: <a href="https://classicalstudies.org/annual-meeting/147th-annual-meeting">SCS </a>(Society for Classical Studies)</p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>CINEMA</strong></p>
<p><strong></strong>Journals: <a href="http://offscreen.com/">Offscreen</a> /<a href="http://sensesofcinema.com/">Senses of Cinema</a></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>COMPARATIVE/WORLD LITERATURE</strong></p>
<p>Journals: <a href="http://www.psupress.org/journals/jnls_cls.html">Comparative Literature Studies</a>, <a href="http://complit.dukejournals.org/">Comparative Literature</a>, <a href="http://www.brill.com/products/journal/journal-world-literature">Journal of World Literature</a> (Brill), <a href="http://docs.lib.purdue.edu/clcweb/">CLCWeb: Comparative Literature and Culture</a>. See also <a href="http://www.acla.org/resources/journals">List of ACLA Journals</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>Conferences: <a href="http://www.acla.org/">ACLA </a>(American Comparative Literature Association) /<a href="https://www.mla.org/Convention">MLA </a>(Modern Language Association)/<a href="http://www.luc.edu/mmla/">MMLA </a>(Midwest Modern Language Association) /<a href="https://www.buffalo.edu/nemla/convention.html">NeMLA </a>(New England Modern Language Association) /<a href="http://litsciarts.org/">SLSA </a>(Society for Literature, Science and the Arts) /<a href="http://narrative.georgetown.edu/conferences/">Narrative</a> /<a href="http://complit.yale.edu/graduate-program/graduate-student-handbook">Yale Comparative Literature Graduate Student Conference</a>; <a href="http://wcfia.harvard.edu/seminars/cultural_politics_graduate_student_papers">Graduate Student Papers on Cultural Politics</a> (The Weatherhead Center, chaired by Prof. Roilos)</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>EAST ASIAN</strong></p>
<p>Journals: <a href="http://u.osu.edu/mclc/">Modern Chinese Literature and Culture</a> /<a href="https://www.dukeupress.edu/Journal-of-Chinese-Literature-and-Culture/">Journal of Chinese Literature and Culture</a>/ <a href="http://www.chineselit.com/">CLEAR</a> (Chinese Literature: Essays, Articles, Reviews)/<a href="http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayJournal?jid=JAS">Journal of Asian Studies</a> /<a href="https://depts.washington.edu/jjs/">Journal of Japanese Studies </a>/<a href="https://jsis.washington.edu/korea/jks/">Journal of Korean Studies</a> /<a href="http://asiacenter.harvard.edu/programs/harvard-asia-quarterly">Harvard Asia Quarterly</a> (Harvard Asia Center)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Conferences: <a href="http://www.asian-studies.org/Conferences/AAS">Chinese Comparative Literature Association /Association for Asian Studies Annual Conference</a> /<a href="https://networks.h-net.org/node/20904/discussions/66865/cfp-24th-annual-meeting-association-japanese-literary-studies-uiuc">Association for Japanese Literary Studies Annual Conference</a> /<a href="https://sites.lsa.umich.edu/ncks-blog/call-for-papers-4th-international-conference-of-nextgen-korean-studies-scholars-nekst/">NEKST</a> (NextGen Korean Studies Scholars)</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>ENGLISH  </strong></p>
<p>Journals: <a href="http://www.euppublishing.com/journal/rom">Romanticism</a> /<a href="https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/eighteenth-century_studies/">ECS </a>(Eighteenth Century Studies) /<a href="https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/english_literary_history/">ELH </a>(English Literary History) /<a href="http://www.press.uillinois.edu/journals/jegp.html">JEGP </a>(Journal of English and German Philology) /<a href="http://www.sel.rice.edu/">SEL </a>(Studies in English Literature) /<a href="http://www.journals.uchicago.edu/toc/mp/current">MP </a>(Modern Philology)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Conferences: <a href="https://asecs.press.jhu.edu/">ASECS</a> (American Society of 18th-c Studies) /<a href="http://www.nassr.ca/conferences">NASSR</a> (North American Society for the Study of Romanticism) /<a href="http://www.bars.ac.uk/events/intconf.php">BARS</a> (British Association for Romantic Studies) /<a href="https://newcollege.asu.edu/navsa2016">NAVSA</a> (North American Victorian Studies Association)</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>FRENCH</strong></p>
<p>Journals: <a href="http://sites.uconn.edu/">Contemporary French and Francophone Studies /Sites</a> /<a href="http://www.nebraskapress.unl.edu/product/French-Forum,673224.aspx">French Forum</a> /<a href="https://espritcreateur.org/">L'Esprit créateur</a> /<a href="http://www.ncfs-journal.org/">19th Century French Studies</a> /<a href="http://newprairiepress.org/sttcl/">Studies in 20th and 21st Century Literature</a> /<a href="http://www.sfs.ac.uk/publications/">French Studies </a>(UK) /<a href="http://www.columbia.edu/cu/french/romanicreview/">Romantic Review</a> /<a href="https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/new_literary_history/">New Literary History</a>/<a href="http://romancesphere.fas.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k56942&amp;tabgroupid=icb.tabgroup138800">Romance Sphere </a>(Harvard RLL)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Conferences:<a href="https://www.mla.org/Convention">MLA </a>(Modern Languages Association)  (divisions by century) / <a href="http://www.slu.edu/~dnickol1/wp/?page_id=10">20th and 21st Century French and Francophone Colloquium</a>/<a href="https://www.brown.edu/conference/french-studies-colloquium/">19th century French Studies Association</a> /<a href="https://kflc.as.uky.edu/">Kentucky Foreign Language Conference</a> (Lexington) /<a href="http://www.sfs.ac.uk/conferences/">Society for French Studies</a> (UK)</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>GERMAN</strong></p>
<p>Journals: <a href="http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1111/(ISSN)1756-1183">German Quarterly</a> /<a href="http://ngc.dukejournals.org/">New German Critique</a> /<a href="http://monatshefte.org/">Monatshefte </a>/<a href="https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/german_studies_review/">German Studies Review</a> /<a href="http://www.uni-konstanz.de/dvjs/editorial.htm">Deutsche Vierteljahrsschrift für Literaturund Geistesgeschichte</a> /<a href="http://www.poeticamagazine.com/">Poetica</a> /<a href="http://www.utpjournals.com/Seminar">Seminar</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>Conferences:<a href="https://www.thegsa.org/conference/current.html"> GSA</a> (German Studies Association), <a href="http://goethesociety.org/conferences/">The Goethe Society of North America</a></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>JEWISH STUDIES</strong></p>
<p>Journal: <a href="http:/www.iupress.indiana.edu/pages.php?pID=89&amp;CDpath=4">Prooftexts: A Journal of Jewish Literary History</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>Conferences: <a href="http:/www.ajsnet.org/conferences.htm">Association for Jewish Studies</a></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>MEDITERRANEAN STUDIES</strong></p>
<p>Conference: <a href="https:/meditopos.rll.lsa.umich.edu/the-meditopos-conference/">The Meditopos Conference at University of Michigan</a></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>MIDDLE EASTERN</strong></p>
<p>Journals:<a href="http://www.brill.com/journal-arabic-literature"> Journal of Arabic Literature</a>/<a href="http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/gede20/current">Edebiyat</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>Conference: <a href="http://mesana.org/annual-meeting/">MESA </a>(Middle East Studies Association)</p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>MODERNISM</strong></p>
<p>Conference: <a href="https:/msa.press.jhu.edu/conferences/">MSA </a>(Modernist Studies Association)</p>
<p></p>
<p>Journal: <a href="https://www.press.jhu.edu/journals/modernism_modernity/">Modernism/Modernity</a>, <a href="http://www.utpjournals.press/loi/md">Modern Drama</a></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>ORAL TRADITION</strong></p>
<p>Journal: <a href="http://journal.oraltradition.org/">Oral Tradition</a></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>SLAVIC</strong>  </p>
<p>Journals:  <a href="http://www.russianreview.org/">The Russian Review</a> /<a href="http://www.slavicreview.illinois.edu/">The Slavic Review</a> /<a href="http://www.aatseel.org/publications/">The Slavic and East European Journal</a></p>
<p></p>
<p>Conferences:  <a href="http:/www.aatseel.org/program/">AATSEEL</a> (American Association of Teachers of Slavic and East European Languages), <a href="http://aseees.org/convention">ASEEES</a> (Association of Slavic, East European and Eurasian Studies)</p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>YIDDISH</strong></p>
<p>Journal:<a href="http://ingeveb.org/"> In geveb</a></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate" >GRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Admissions                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114691" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	Although we are here to answer your questions, it is helpful to first acquaint yourself with the following sources of information. A good place to start is the Comparative Literature program description at the <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/programs_of_study/comparative_literature.php" target="_blank">Graduate School of Arts and Sciences</a>. General information about financial aid can be found at <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/prospective_students/financial_aid.php" target="_blank">www.gsas.harvard.edu/prospective_students/financial_aid.php</a>. See our Q&amp;A below for information on the department's financial aid, offered to all admitted students.<br /><br />Locating <a href="http://courses.my.harvard.edu">courses</a> that are offered can be a good way to check out which faculty are teaching what courses and if your research interests would be met in our program.
</p>

<p>
	You may apply for admission on-line or request an application packet from <a href="https://gsas.harvard.edu/admissions/apply">https://gsas.harvard.edu/admissions/apply</a>.<br /><br />And finally, there is a Q&amp;A section (below) of questions most often asked that may provide added information. Happy researching!.<br /><br /><strong><em>General Guidelines for Admissions:</em></strong> The following is a set of general guidelines for the Department of Comparative Literature’s graduate admissions process. While several areas are emphasized here, the Admissions Committee carefully examines the overall profile of each applicant, taking these and other aspects of the candidate's application into consideration.<br /><br /><strong><em>The Application:</em></strong> Requests for applications and inquiries about financial aid should be addressed to <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank">www.gsas.harvard.edu</a>. The application can be filled out on-line at the same address. You should make every effort to ensure that all supporting materials (transcripts, recommendations) arrive by the application deadline. No applications for admission will be accepted after the deadline set by GSAS.<br /><br /><strong><em>The Writing Sample:</em></strong> The writing sample is supposed to demonstrate your ability to engage in literary criticism and/or theory. It can be a paper written for a course or a section of a senior thesis or essay. It is usually between 10-20 pages. Do not send longer papers with instructions to read an excerpt; you should edit the sample so that it is no longer than 20 pages.  Writing samples should be in English, although candidates are permitted to submit an additional writing sample written in a different language.<br /><br /><strong><em>Statement of Purpose:</em></strong> The Statement of Purpose should give the admissions committee a clear sense of your individual interests and strengths. You need not indicate at the time of application precisely what your field of specialization will be, but it is helpful to tell us about your aspirations and how the Comparative Literature department at Harvard might help in attaining these goals. These statements are usually between one and four pages long.<br /><br /><strong><em>Recommendations:</em></strong> It is important to have strong letters of recommendation from professors who are familiar with your academic work. An applicant who has been out of school for several years should try to reestablish contact with former professors. Additional letters from employers may also be included.<br /><br /><strong><em>Subject and program number:</em></strong> Our Harvard GSAS subject and program number is 1700 - this number is for use on the Harvard application.  
</p>

<p>
	<br /><strong><em>Graduate Record Examination (GRE) codes:</em></strong> GRE s<span>cores should be reported to Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, Code 3451.</span><br /><br />For more information on our graduate program, please contact our Director of Graduate Studies, <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/verna-conley" title="">Professor Verena Conley </a>(<a href="mailto:vconley@fas.harvard.edu">vconley@fas.harvard.edu</a>)
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1391450135" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_sv_list_box"  module="boxes" delta="1391450135"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Questions and Answers</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1391450135' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id='box-1391450135-page' data-page='0' data-delta='1391450135' class='os-sv-list os_sv_list_box sv-list-faq sv-list-view-teaser sv-list-layout-list sv-grid-3'><article id="node-141051" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/where-should-i-start" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Where should I start? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>&#13;
	The best place to start is with the admissions website: <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank" target="_top">www.gsas.harvard.edu</a> (which also contains the link for the Comparative Literature program description) and with the course catalogue at <a data-url="https://courses.my.harvard.edu/" href="https://courses.my.harvard.edu/" title="" target="_top">https://courses.my.harvard.edu/</a>. This gives you an idea of who is teaching what and whether your interests are well represented at Harvard. This also gives you the foundation from which to ask specific questions.&#13;
</p>&#13;
 <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/where-should-i-start" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Where should I start? </span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141061" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-about-g%E2%80%99s-gre-and-gpa" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What about the G’s? GRE and GPA </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>While a high score in the verbal part of the test is a positive addition to the application, it is by no means the most important aspect of a candidacy. You should plan to take the GRE as early as possible and it should not be taken later than October in order to ensure arrival of scores as part of the application. December exam results can arrive too late to be considered. We do not require a GRE subject test.<br /><br />We do not ask for GPA but your overall grades do play an important role in the application process.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141066" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/must-i-already-know-four-languages-apply" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Must I already know four languages to apply? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>We pay careful attention in evaluating prospective applicants to make sure that they would be able to satisfy our program requirements in a reasonable span of time. Our program requires declaring four languages, with coursework in three of them (one of which may be English). Most students we admit have a solid grounding in two literatures and languages and have had exposure to another (or more). Our program allows time for further language study as well. It is important for your application to give a clear idea of what level of language preparation you have. For instance, languages listed</p> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/must-i-already-know-four-languages-apply" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Must I already know four languages to apply? </span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141071" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-apply-am-degree" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I apply for the AM degree? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>No. You can take a master’s degree only if you are enrolled at Harvard College as an undergraduate. The only way to enter Comparative Literature is through the Ph.D. program, although once you are enrolled in our program you may take the A.M. degree in passing.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141076" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-speak-current-students" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I speak with current students? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Because we have over a hundred applicants annually and far more requests that do not result in applications, we tend to economize on the time of our students, who are the centerpiece and raison d’être of the whole program, by not involving them officially until after students have been admitted, at which point we put candidates in touch with students who have similar interests. Before then, potential applicants are welcome to contact students whom they know, but we do not connect applicants with students ourselves.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141081" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-kind-financial-aid-available" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What kind of financial aid is available? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>&#13;
	The Graduate School provides five years of full funding to each student admitted by our department, including tuition, medical insurance, and either a fellowship stipend or teaching fellow support for living expenses (currently $33,624 for 2017-18). Incoming students will receive three years of stipendiary support (straight scholarship, no teaching), usually taken in the 1st, 2nd, and final years, and two years of teaching fellow support (assisting in courses or tutoring in our undergraduate Literature Concentration), usually done in the 3rd and 4th years. There is also a fifth year of</p> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-kind-financial-aid-available" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What kind of financial aid is available? </span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141096" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/should-i-visit-campus-admissions-are-announced" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Should I visit the campus before admissions are announced? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Department receives many inquiries each year from prospective students. We have found that in terms of arranging appointments with faculty, what makes the most sense is to focus our efforts on the period after applicants have found out whether or not they have been accepted. Applicants are, of course, free to contact individual faculty and request information or appointments.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141126" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-should-my-preparation-be" rel="bookmark" target="_top">What should my preparation be? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Department has been consistent across the years in paying close attention to the backgrounds of candidates in languages and literatures. Usually the Committee focuses on candidates who have a solid grounding in one language and literature as well as knowledge of at least one other language and a more than passing exposure to its literature. In considering the strongest applicants, the committee looks particularly to whether or not they would be able to complete the demanding course and exam requirements of the program in a timely fashion. That said, the Department is eclectic in that</p> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/what-should-my-preparation-be" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about What should my preparation be? </span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141141" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/who-must-take-toefl" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Who must take the TOEFL? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The University requires that all applicants whose first language is not English must have taken the TOEFL within the last two years or have an undergraduate degree from an English-speaking College or University. Individual courses taken in English or at English-speaking universities do not count in place of a TOEFL.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141156" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-transfer-course-credits-my-master%E2%80%99s-degree" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I transfer course credits from my Master’s degree? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Some students come to our program having already completed some graduate work. At the end of the first semester, credits for prior graduate work are considered on a case-by-case basis by the Director of Graduate Studies. A maximum of six credits can be granted for courses that we determine are the equivalent of our graduate courses. There are restrictions about which requirement the credits can count for; these guidelines are listed in the Graduate Student Guide under “Credit for Graduate Work Done Elsewhere.”</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
<article id="node-141161" class="node node-faq node-teaser article clearfix" role="article" target="_top">
  
      <header class="toggle node-header">
              <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
          <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-apply-admission-spring-semester" rel="bookmark" target="_top">Can I apply for admission for the Spring semester? </a>
        </h1>
          </header>
  
  
  <div class="os-slider node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>&#13;
	No, students admitted to the program enter in September only. For more information on our graduate program, please contact our Director of Graduate Studies, <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/verna-conley" title="" target="_top">Professor Verena Conley </a>(<a href="mailto:vconley@fas.harvard.edu" target="_top">vconley@fas.harvard.edu</a>)&#13;
</p>&#13;
 <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/faq/can-i-apply-admission-spring-semester" class="node-readmore" target="_top">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Can I apply for admission for the Spring semester? </span></a></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

<!--FLEXIBLE ADMIN HEADER FOR USE BY SELECT GROUPS USING OS-->
	<div id="branding_header">
		<div  class="branding-container clearfix">

					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/about" >ABOUT</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>

															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Contact                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-92716" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong><img height="355" width="600" alt="Dana Palmer House" title="Dana Palmer House" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/complit/files/dana_palmer_house_david.jpg?m=1389209970&amp;itok=8-u3lp91" /></strong></p>
<p><strong>Department of Comparative Literature</strong><br />16 Quincy Street<br />Dana-Palmer House<br />Cambridge, MA 02138<br />Phone: 617-495-1900<br /><br /><strong>Please see our <a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/role/department-administration">Department Administration</a> list to help you determine who best to contact with your inquiry.</strong></p>
<p></p><div class="media media-element-container media-default"><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-default"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe width="425" height="350" frameborder="0" scrolling="no" marginheight="350" marginwidth="425" src="https://maps.google.com/maps?q=16+Quincy+Street+Cambridge,+MA+02138&amp;hl=en&amp;sll=42.036922,-71.683501&amp;sspn=2.007261,4.515381&amp;hnear=16+Quincy+St,+Cambridge,+Massachusetts+02138&amp;t=m&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;hq=&amp;ll=42.373004,-71.114877&amp;spn=0.016677,0.025706&amp;z=14&amp;output=embed"></iframe><br /><small><a href="https://maps.google.com/maps?q=16+Quincy+Street+Cambridge,+MA+02138&amp;hl=en&amp;sll=42.036922,-71.683501&amp;sspn=2.007261,4.515381&amp;hnear=16+Quincy+St,+Cambridge,+Massachusetts+02138&amp;t=m&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;hq=&amp;ll=42.373004,-71.114877&amp;spn=0.016677,0.025706&amp;z=14&amp;source=embed" style="color:#0000FF;text-align:left">View Larger Map</a></small></div></div></div></div>
<p><strong><strong>Here is a link to the <a href="http://map.harvard.edu/">Harvard Campus Map</a>.</strong></strong></p>
<p><strong>For general directions to Harvard University, please visit <a href="http://www.harvard.edu/visitors/directions">this page</a>.</strong></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Forms and Resources                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114706" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="column">
	<p>
		<strong>All forms are available for download on the <a href="http://hwpi.harvard.edu/complit-intranet">Department Intranet</a>:</strong>
	</p>

	<p>
		Adviser Form<br />Permission to Count a 100-Level Course for Graduate Credit
	</p>
</div>

<h2>
	G1 Forms
</h2>

<p>
	Course level petition form (Permission to Count One 1-99-Level Course For 100-Level Credit).
</p>

<h2>
	G2 Forms
</h2>

<p>
	Secondary Year Paper for G2
</p>

<h2>
	G3 Forms
</h2>

<p>
	PhD Orals Approval of Major and Minor Fields Reading Lists.
</p>

<h2>
	G4 Forms
</h2>

<p>
	Prospectus Conference form.
</p>

<p>
	 
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1391443605" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html"  module="boxes" delta="1391443605"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Pages of Interest:</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1391443605' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h4>
	<strong><em>General Interest:</em></strong>
</h4>

<p>
	<a href="http://www.hio.harvard.edu/index.php" target="_blank"><strong><em>Harvard International Office</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~dudley/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Dudley House</em></strong></a> -- Graduate Student House<br /><br /><a href="http://hcl.harvard.edu/hfa/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Harvard Film Archives</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/current_students/financial_aid.php" target="_blank"><strong><em>GSAS financial aid information</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><em><strong><a href="http://huhs.harvard.edu/">Harvard University Health Services</a></strong></em><br /><br /><a href="http://hcs.harvard.edu/~gsc" target="_blank"><strong><em>Graduate Student Council</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><a href="http://www.summer.harvard.edu/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Harvard Summer School</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><br /><strong><em>Research Centers and Institutes:</em></strong>
</p>

<p>
	<a href="http://daviscenter.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Davis Center for Russian Studies</em></strong></a> -- Harvard’s center for interdisciplinary research and study of Russia and the countries surrounding it.<br /><br /><a href="http://www.huri.harvard.edu/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Harvard Ukrainian Research Center</em></strong></a> -- Research is conducted on Ukrainian language, literature, and history as well as in anthropology, archaeology, art history, economics, political science, sociology, theology, and other disciplines.<br /><br /><a href="http://www.harvard-yenching.org/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Yenching Institute</em></strong></a> -- A nonprofit foundation dedicated to the advancement of higher education in the humanities and social sciences in East and Southeast Asia<br /><br /><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~cjs/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Center for Jewish Studies</em></strong></a> -- The center is the focal point for the study and teaching of Judaica through publications, fellowships, lectures, and symposia on topics of interest to scholars and to the general public.<br /><br /><em><strong><a href="http://drclas.harvard.edu/">David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies</a> </strong></em>-- The Center works to increase knowledge of the cultures, histories, environment, and contemporary affairs of Latin America.<br /><br /><a href="http://www.hds.harvard.edu/cswr" target="_blank"><strong><em>Center for the Study of World Religions</em></strong></a> -- The Center focuses on the study of religious life in communities throughout the world and throughout human history.<br /><br /><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~rijs" target="_blank"><strong><em>Reischauer Institute of Japanese Studies</em></strong></a> -- The Center conducts research on Japan and provides a forum for related academic activities and the exchange of ideas. It seeks to stimulate scholarly and public interest in Japan and Japanese studies at Harvard and around the world.
</p>

<p>
	<br /><a href="http://korea.fas.harvard.edu/" target="_blank"><strong><em>Korea Institute</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><strong><em><a href="http://asiacenter.harvard.edu/">Asia Center</a></em></strong>
</p>

<p>
	<em><strong><a href="http://fairbank.fas.harvard.edu/home">Fairbank Center for Chinese Studies</a></strong></em>
</p>

<h4>
	 
</h4>

<p>
	<strong style="font-family:georgia, sans-serif; font-size:19px"><em>Teaching Resources:</em></strong>
</p>

<p>
	<em><strong><a href="http://bokcenter.harvard.edu/">Derek Bok Center for Teaching and Learning</a></strong></em><br /><br /><a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/images/stories/pdfs/teachfell.pdf" target="_blank"><strong><em>Teaching Fellow Handbook</em></strong></a> <br /> 
</p>

<h4>
	<strong><em>Allied Calendars:</em></strong>
</h4>

<p>
	<a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~du_bois/news_events/current_calendar.html" target="_blank"><strong><em>African-American Studies Calendar (W.E.B. Du Bois Institute)</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><a href="http://cmes.hmdc.harvard.edu/event" target="_blank"><strong><em>Center for Middle Eastern Studies calendar</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~classics/calendar.html" target="_blank"><strong><em>Classics Calendar</em></strong></a> 
</p>

<p>
	<em><strong><a href="http://ealc.fas.harvard.edu/calendar">East Asian Studies Calendar</a></strong></em>
</p>

<p>
	<a href="http://english.fas.harvard.edu/events/events-calendar" target="_blank"><strong><em>English Calendar</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><strong><em><a href="http://fairbank.fas.harvard.edu/events/" title="">Fairbank Center for Chinese Studies Calendar</a></em></strong>
</p>

<p>
	<em><strong><a href="http://history.fas.harvard.edu/calendar/index.php">History Calendar</a> </strong></em><br /><br /><a href="http://mahindrahumanities.fas.harvard.edu" target="_blank" title=""><strong><em>Mahindra Humanities Center</em></strong></a><br /><br /><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~iaas/luncheon.html" target="_blank"><strong><em>Inner Asian and Altaic Studies Calendar</em></strong></a>
</p>

<p>
	<em><strong><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~cjs/events/events.html">Center for Jewish Studies</a></strong></em><br /><br /><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~medieval/events" target="_blank"><strong><em>Medieval Studies Calendar</em></strong></a> 
</p>

<p>
	<em><strong><a href="http://nelc.fas.harvard.edu/calendar-nelc">NELC Calendar</a> </strong></em><br /><br /><em><strong><a href="http://rll.fas.harvard.edu/calendar">Romance Languages and Literatures Calendar</a> </strong></em><br /><br /><em><strong><a href="http://sas.fas.harvard.edu/calendar/upcoming">Sanskrit and Indian Studies Calendar</a></strong></em><br /><br /><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~slavic/events/current_events.htm" target="_blank"><strong><em>Slavic Languages Calendar</em></strong></a> <br /><br /><strong><em><a href="http://www.ves.fas.harvard.edu/" title="">VES: Department of Visual and Environmental Studies</a></em></strong>
</p>

<h4>
	<strong><em>Professional Organizations:</em></strong>
</h4>

<p>
	<a href="http://www.mla.org/" target="_blank"><strong><em>The Modern Language Association</em></strong></a> - MLA<br /><br /><a href="http://www.acla.org/" target="_blank"><strong><em>The American Comparative Literature Association</em></strong></a> - ACLA<br /><br /><em><strong><a href="http://www.apaonline.org/">American Philological Association</a></strong></em>
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>																																			</div>

<meta name="description" content="Harvard University has offered courses in Comparative Literature since 1894; the Department of Comparative Literature was established by vote of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences on April 10, 1906. The department was reorganized in 2007 in a merger with the formerly separate undergraduate Literature Concentration. The present program is the result of a thorough review and revision of both the graduate and undergraduate programs undertaken during the academic year 2009-2010 and refined annually." />
<meta property="og:description" content="Harvard University has offered courses in Comparative Literature since 1894; the Department of Comparative Literature was established by vote of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences on April 10, 1906. The department was reorganized in 2007 in a merger with the formerly separate undergraduate Literature Concentration. The present program is the result of a thorough review and revision of both the graduate and undergraduate programs undertaken during the academic year 2009-2010 and refined annually." />
<meta property="og:title" content="Guide for Graduate Students" />

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1443549664" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1443549664"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

even  "><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/publication-subsidies" >Publication Subsidies </a></li><li class="menu-4407 menu-path-node-127646   odd  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research-guides"  title="">Library Research Guides</a></li><li class="menu-4679 menu-path-node-114746   even   last "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/visiting-scholars"  title="">Visiting Scholars Application</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-3473 menuparent  menu-path-node-92671   even   last "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/about"  title="">About</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-4405 menu-path-node-92716  first   odd   last "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/contact" >Contact</a></li></ul></li></ul>

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate" >GRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Guide for Graduate Students                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114701" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="column">
	<p>
		Harvard University has offered courses in Comparative Literature since 1894; the Department of Comparative Literature was established by vote of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences on April 10, 1906. The department was reorganized in 2007 in a merger with the formerly separate undergraduate Literature Concentration. The present program is the result of a thorough review and revision of both the graduate and undergraduate programs undertaken during the academic year 2009-2010 and refined annually.
	</p>

	<p>
		Please take the time to read through the entire Guide. Please also keep the Guide for consultation. A careful perusal now, even if you are just beginning your graduate studies at Harvard, will help you to think of your program as an organic whole. Your courses, examinations, teaching, and dissertation enable you to pursue your intellectual interests while simultaneously acquiring credentials to obtain appointments in teaching and research as well as other forms of employment. 
	</p>
</div>
</div></div></div><table class="os-files-other-list">
<tbody>
 <tr class="odd"><td class="mime mime-pdf"><img class="file-icon" alt="" src="/profiles/openscholar/modules/os/modules/os_files/icons/application-pdf.svg" /></td><td class="file"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/files/complit/files/guide_for_graduate_students_in_the_department_of_comparative_literature_2017-2018.pdf" >guide_for_graduate_students_in_the_department_of_comparative_literature_2017-2018.pdf</a></td><td class="size">812 KB</td> </tr>
</tbody>
</table>
  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-38531"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate"  class="active-trail active">Graduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42881"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admissions" >Admissions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42891"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/forms-and-resources" >Forms and Resources</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-131331"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/journalsconferences-graduate-students" >Journals/Conferences for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-42886"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/guide-graduate-students"  class="active-trail active active">Guide for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-45931"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-dissertations" >PhD Dissertations</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42896"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/poggioli-colloquium" >Poggioli Faculty/Student Colloquium</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48421"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/teaching" >Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-106121"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-alumni" >Graduate Alumni</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-108431"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/alumni-connect" >Alumni Directory </a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-146616"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-field-comparative-literature" >Secondary Field in Comparative Literature</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Concentrators                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114676" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>General Information<br /><br /></h2>
<p>The undergraduate concentration in Comparative Literature offers students the opportunity to design a program of study that works across languages, cultures, and media in a comparative and interdisciplinary context. The open, flexible nature of the concentration allows students to develop an individualized program of study that incorporates literary and cultural analysis in the exploration of any number of fields and disciplines both within and beyond the Humanities. Some students, for example, develop a curriculum in Literature and the Arts, linking the study of literature with film, music, theater, digital media, or creative writing.  Others design programs that connect literary study to contemporary concerns and disciplines beyond the Humanities, focusing their work on the relationship between Literature and Medicine, for example, or Literature and Law, or Literature and Ethics.  Still other students find in the study of Comparative Literature a place for the comparative study of multiple literatures, World Literature, and translation, or the examination of aesthetics, philosophy, and literary and cultural theory. In short, the undergraduate program in Comparative Literature provides an ideal home for students who wish to craft a comparative and interdisciplinary concentration that is embedded in the Humanities but has the potential to reach beyond.</p>
<p> Read more about the Comparative Literature Concentration in the <a href="http://handbook.fas.harvard.edu/book/comparative-literature">Harvard College Handbook for Students</a>.</p>
<p></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-38526"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active">Undergraduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-42866"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/prospective-students" >Prospective Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56516"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/sophomores" >Sophomores</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56526"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/juniors" >Juniors</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56531"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/seniors" >Seniors</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-125981"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/tutorial-board" >Comp Lit Undergraduate Tutorial Board</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42876"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/secondary-field-literature" >Secondary Field in Comparative Literature</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-52311"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate-alumni" >Undergraduate Alumni</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->

<div id="page" class="container page os_pages-section-92681 header-main content-top footer-left footer footer-right">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1443549664" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1443549664"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1443549664' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-522611" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

                    <h1 id="page-title">

    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p style="text-align:left">
	<strong>2016-2017</strong>
</p>

<address style="text-align:left">
	<strong><span><span>Every Step a New Movement: Anarchism in the Stalin-Era Literature of the Absurd and its Post-Soviet Adaptations</span></span></strong>
</address>

<div style="text-align:left">
	Ania Aizman
</div>

<address style="text-align:left">
	 
</address>

<address style="text-align:left">

	Julia Alekseyeva
</div>

<address style="text-align:left">

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	2004-05
</h4>

<p>
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">

</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>An Old French Life of Saint Agnes, and other Vernacular Versions of the Middle Ages.</strong></em> <br />Alexander Joseph Denomy, Jr.<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1932
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>Die Diesseits-Jenseits Spannung in der Englischen Barocklyrik.</strong></em> <br />Werner Paul Friederich<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1928
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>Two J Versions of the Historia preliis in Italian Prose, with an Edition of the Nobili fatti che ff'e Alesandro di Macedonia, from MS. II, I, 62, of the Biblioteca Nazionale Centrale di Firenze.</strong></em> <br />Charles Arthur Messner<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1921
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>Amadas et Ydoine:<br />A Study in Comparative Literature.</strong></em> <br />John Revell Reinhard<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1917
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>The Development of Plot and Characterization in Early Greek and Early Elizabethan Tragedy, with Especial Reference to Aeschylus and Marlowe.</strong></em> <br />James Buell Munn<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1916
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>The Contribution of G. F. Müller to Russian Historiography, with Some Consideration of A.L. Schlözer.</strong></em> <br />Samuel Hazzard Cross<br /><br /><strong><em>The Mediaeval Conception of Tragedy and Comedy</em></strong><br />Amos Philip McMahon<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1913
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>The Relation of Giacomo Leopardi to Classical Antiquity.</strong></em> <br />John Van Horne<br /><br /><em><strong>Christine de Pisan and the Victorine Revival:<br />An Essay on Some of the Mediaeval Elements in French Classical Criticism.</strong></em> <br />Maud Elizabeth Temple, A.M.<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1911
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>The Supernatural in Tragedy.</strong></em> <br />Charles Edward Whitmore<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1910
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>The Relations between Prose and Metrical Composition in Old Norse Literature.</strong></em> <br />Henry Adams Bellows<br /><br /><em><strong>The Comedies of Holberg:<br />A Study in Comparative Literature.</strong></em> <br />Oscar James Campbell, Jr.<br /><br /><em><strong>Mediaeval Visions of the Other World.</strong></em> <br />Henry Wadsworth Longfellow Dana<br /> 
</p>

<h4 style="text-align:left">
	1904
</h4>

<p style="text-align:left">
	 
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	<em><strong>Some Notes on Italian Borrowings from England in the Eighteenth Century.</strong></em> <br />Arthur Beckwith Myrick
</p>

<p style="text-align:left">
	Inquiries about dissertations can be made to the Harvard University Archives for Harvard dissertations at 617-495-2461. Students and faculty of Harvard University may request copies of dissertations, please see<a href="http://askarc.hul.harvard.edu/faq/195748" title=""> this page</a> for more details.
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1443549664" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1443549664"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1443549664' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-522611" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/files/complit/files/banner_department_of_comparative_literature.jpg?m=1508249831">banner_department_of_comparative_literature.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/complit/files/banner_department_of_comparative_literature.jpg?m=1499733535&amp;itok=hgFFPlFb" width="980" height="170" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>

  </div></div></div></div>					  					  					  				 </div>

				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">
