		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate" >GRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Poggioli Faculty/Student Colloquium                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114716" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div>
	<p>
		The Poggioli Faculty/Student Colloquium is a monthly meeting of graduate students, faculty, and guests from Comparative Literature and other related disciplines, featuring two speakers, one graduate student and one faculty member, and two discussants, one graduate student and one faculty member.
	</p>

	<p>
		The objectives of the Colloquium are two-fold:
	</p>

	<ul><li>
			  to simulate a conference-style forum in order to engage in a deeper intellectual conversation about one's work
		</li>
		<li>
			 to receive practical feedback and suggestions regarding professionalization (presentation skills, public performance, etc.).
		</li>
	</ul><p>
		Each presentation is 15 minutes, followed by a 5-minute response and 20-30 minutes of open discussion. 
	</p>

	<p>
		Meetings are on Tuesdays, 6pm, in the Dana-Palmer Seminar Room. Refreshments provided.
	</p>

	<p>
		Note: the Poggioli Colloquium also functions as part of CL 243 A, B, and C: Professing Literature 1, 2, and 3.  For more information, please contact Jasmine Hu, Departmental Teaching Fellow (<a href="mailto:yni@fas.harvard.edu">jasminehu@fas.harvard.edu</a>).
	</p>

	<p>
		 
	</p>
</div>

<div>
	<p>
		<strong><span style="text-decoration:underline">Fall 2017 Schedule:</span></strong>
	</p>

	<p>
		<strong>October 3, 2017 –Poggioli Colloquium 1</strong><br /><br /><strong>November 7, 2017 – Poggioli Colloquium 2 </strong><br /><br /><strong>December 5, 2017 – Poggioli Colloquium 3 </strong><br /> 
	</p>
</div>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-38531"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate"  class="active-trail active">Graduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42881"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admissions" >Admissions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42891"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/forms-and-resources" >Forms and Resources</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-131331"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/journalsconferences-graduate-students" >Journals/Conferences for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42886"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/guide-graduate-students" >Guide for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-45931"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-dissertations" >PhD Dissertations</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-42896"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/poggioli-colloquium"  class="active-trail active active">Poggioli Faculty/Student Colloquium</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48421"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/teaching" >Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-106121"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-alumni" >Graduate Alumni</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-108431"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/alumni-connect" >Alumni Directory </a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-146616"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-field-comparative-literature" >Secondary Field in Comparative Literature</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Prospective Students                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114666" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p style="margin-left:1.5pt">
	<strong>The undergraduate program in Comparative Literature at Harvard prepares students to play an active and creative role in today’s globalized world by exploring literature and culture across languages, and investigating the intersections and inter-connections among literatures, cultures, media, and disciplines. </strong>
</p>

<p style="margin-left:1.5pt">
	Students in Comparative Literature design a course of study tailored to their particular interests, and work in languages as diverse as English and German, French and Hindi, Spanish and Arabic, Chinese and Latin.  Some students have fluency in their foreign language(s) of choice when they join the program, while others develop their linguistic fluency as they pursue their studies in the concentration. Comp Lit concentrators can connect their literary studies with broader interests in the Humanities, such as film, digital media, and music.  They can also incorporate their literary studies into their interests in other fields, such as law, medicine, and the environment. Many of our students bring a comparative disciplinary element into their program of studies (literature and gender studies; literature and philosophy; literature and government), while others pursue a joint concentration directly.
</p>

<p style="margin-right:1.5pt; margin-bottom:0in; margin-left:1.5pt; margin-bottom:.0001pt">
	If you are interested in concentrating in Comparative Literature, our Director of Undergraduate Studies, Dr. Sandra Naddaff, will be happy to answer any of your questions. She also holds office hours by appointment (Fall 2017 Office Hours: Wednesdays 4:30-6m). Please call (617-495-4186) or email our <a href="mailto:mignotte@fas.harvard.edu">Program Coordinator</a> if you wish to sign up for an appointment. You may also email Dr. Naddaff directly (<a href="mailto:snaddaff@fas.harvard.edu">snaddaff@fas.harvard.edu</a>) with any questions you might have. <br /><br />We look forward to hearing from you and to meeting many of you in the coming year!<br /> 
</p>

<h2 style="margin-right:1.5pt; margin-left:1.5pt; margin-bottom:0.0001pt">
	Fall 2017 events:
</h2>

<p style="margin-right:1.5pt; margin-bottom:0in; margin-left:1.5pt; margin-bottom:.0001pt">
	<span>This fall, we have organized several events that are designed to introduce you to what it is like to be a concentrator in our department.  You are encouraged to attend at least one of the following events:</span><br /> 
</p>

<ul style="margin-top:0in"><li>
		<b>Oct. 10</b>, Tuesday, 12:30-2 pm, Dana Palmer Seminar Room: An Informal Lunch with Comp Lit Concentrators and Faculty. Feel free to drop in for even just a few minutes and talk informally with members of the department about the undergraduate Comp Lit program. <span style="color:#1f497d">-<a href="https://www.facebook.com/events/1416999391729143">FB Event page</a>-</span><br /> 
	</li>
	<li>
		<b>Oct. 11 and 25</b>, Wednesday, 4:30-6 pm, Dana Palmer 209: Office Hours with the Director of Undergraduate Studies in Comp Lit by appointment. Another chance to ask your questions about life in the Comp Lit concentration. Please email Isaure Mignotte (<a href="mailto:mignotte@fas.harvard.edu)" target="_blank">mignotte@fas.harvard.edu)</a> to schedule.<br /> 
	</li>
	<li>
		<b>Oct. 19</b>, Thursday, 2-3.30 pm, Dana Palmer 209: Cookies and Conversation with the Director of Undergraduate Studies in Comp Lit. Stop by and ask any questions you might have about our program (or anything else!). <span style="color:#1f497d">-<a href="https://www.facebook.com/events/862847057215228/">FB Event Page</a> -</span><br /> 
	</li>
	<li>
		<b>Oct. 26</b>, Thursday, 6-6:45 pm, Dana Palmer Seminar room: Join current concentrators for Pizza and Conversation to get the inside scoop on the department. <span style="color:#1f497d">-<a href="https://www.facebook.com/events/183593555521628/">FB Event page</a>-</span>
	</li>
</ul><p>
	Our<a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/how-apply"> Concentration Admission</a> season occurs in the fall for Harvard students in their sophomore year. This year, <a href="/" title="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/prospective-students">applications</a><strong><span> to Comparative Literature are due on Friday, October 27th 2017, by 4 pm</span></strong><span>.</span><br /><br />Please review the <a href="http://handbook.fas.harvard.edu/book/comparative-literature">Harvard College Handbook for Students</a> for a description of the Comparative Literature concentration and its requirements.
</p>

<p>
	Feel free to contact any one of our <strong><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/Peer-advisors" title="">Peer Advisors</a></strong> for more information on what it's like to concentrate in Comparative Literature:
</p>

<p>
	You will also find many more details in our <strong><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/files/complit/files/comp_lit_brochure_linear_fall_2016.doc">Comp Lit brochure.</a></strong>
</p>

<p>
	Students who have concentrated in Comparative Literature have gone on to careers in a variety of fields:  academics, journalism, film, law, medicine, and business, among others. Please see our <strong><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/alumni-list">Alumni List </a></strong>for specific examples. Here are also some testimonies about our concentration from some of our alumni: <strong><strong><a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/alumni-voices">Alumni Voices.</a></strong></strong>
</p>

<p>
	<img height="256" width="776" alt="comp lit without borders" title="comp lit without borders" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/complit/files/comp_lit_without_borders.jpg?m=1506455859&amp;itok=1bZtCNO1" /></p>

<p>
	 
</p>

<p>
	 
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last menu-depth-1 menu-item-4951"><a  class="menu-heading active active active">Useful Links</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-16444"><a href="http://hwpi.harvard.edu/complit-intranet" >Department Intranet</a></li><li class="last leaf leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-4952"><a href="http://iwl.fas.harvard.edu/" >Institute for World Literature</a></li></ul></li></ul></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-solr-search-box" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_search_solr_search_box no-title"  module="boxes" delta="solr_search_box"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/resources" >RESOURCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Publications                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114731" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>Harvard Studies in Comparative Literature</h2>
<p>The Harvard Studies in Comparative Literature series was inaugurated in 1910 by Professor W.H. Schofield with the publication of <em><strong><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Three-Philosophical-Poets-Lucretius-Goethe/dp/1492707341/ref=la_B001HPXQ1M_1_5?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1393533201&amp;sr=1-5">Three Philosophical Poets</a></strong></em> by George Santayana. The series continues to present the work of outstanding scholars to this day. All publications are listed chronologically below. Books can be ordered from amazon.com by clicking on underlined book titles.</p>
<p><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Hyperboles-Rhetoric-Baroque-Literature-Comparative/dp/0674053338/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1393532959&amp;sr=8-1&amp;keywords=hyperboles%2C%20christopher%20johnson"><strong>Hyperboles: The Rhetoric of Excess in Baroque Literature and Thought</strong><br /></a></em>By Christopher D. Johnson<br />2010</p>
<p><strong><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Thin-Culture-High-Art-Nineteenth-Century/dp/067402382X">Thin Culture, High Art: Gogol, Hawthorne, and Authorship in Nineteenth-Century Russia and America</a></em></strong></p>
<p><strong><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Thin-Culture-High-Art-Nineteenth-Century/dp/067402382X"></a></em></strong>By Anne Lounsbery<br />2007</p>
<p> <br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Medieval-Joke-Poetry-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674016645"><strong><em>Medieval Joke Poetry: The Cantigas d'Escarnho e de Mal Dizer</em></strong> </a><a href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~complit/hl_bl_me.htm" target="_blank"><br /></a>By Benjamin Liu <br />2004</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Ascension-Authorship-Attribution-Hellenistic/dp/0674016629"><strong><em>The Ascension of Authorship: Attribution and Canon Formation in Jewish, Hellenistic, and Christian Traditions</em></strong> </a><br />By Jed Wyrick<br />2004</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Soliciting-Darkness-Obscurity-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674012577"><strong><em>Soliciting Darkness: Pindar, Obscurity, and the Classical Tradition</em></strong> </a><br />By John T. Hamilton<br />2003</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Visions-Persia-Olearius-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674012542"><strong><em>Visions of Persia: Mapping the Travels of Adam Olearius</em></strong> </a><br />By Elio Brancaforte<br />2003</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Original-Subjects-Harvard-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674002636"><strong><em>Original Subjects: The Child, the Novel, and the Nation</em></strong> </a><br />By Ala Alryyes<br />2001</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Story-Prostitutes-Good-Nothings/dp/0674839501"><strong><em>The Story of O: Prostitutes and Other Good-for-Nothings in the Renaissance</em></strong> </a><br />By Michele Jaffe<br />1999</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Way-Oblivion-Heraclitus-Comparative/dp/0674948033"><strong><em>The Way of Oblivion: Heraclitus and Kafka</em></strong> </a><br />By David Schur<br />1998</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Subjects-without-Selves-Transitional-Comparative/dp/0674853814"><strong><em>Subjects without Selves: Transitional Texts in Modern Fiction</em></strong> </a><br />By Gabriele Schwab<br />1994</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Challenge-Comparative-Literature-Teach-Yourself/dp/0674106881"><strong><em>The Challenge of Comparative Literature</em></strong> </a><br />By Claudio Guillèn<br />1993</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Death-Quotation-Marks-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674194276"><strong><em>Death in Quotation Marks: Cultural Myths of the Modern Poet</em></strong> </a><br />By Svetlana Boym<br />1991</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Living-Harvard-Studies-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674536649"><strong><em>The Living Eye</em></strong> </a><br />By Jean Starobinski<br />1989</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Mi-lou-Labyrinth-Harvard-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674572750/ref=la_B001HPDDFQ_1_9?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1393534300&amp;sr=1-9"><strong><em>Mi-lou: Poetry and the Labyrinth of Desire</em></strong> </a><br />By Stephen Owen<br />1989</p>
<p><br /><em><strong><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Literary-Structure-Evolution-Value-Structuralism/dp/0674536533">Literary Structure, Evolution, and Value: Russian Formalism and Czech Structuralism Reconsidered</a> </strong></em><br />By Jurij Striedter<br />1989</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Taming-Romanticism-Biedermeier-Comparative/dp/0674868021"><strong><em>The Taming of Romanticism: European Literature and the Age of Biedermeier</em></strong> </a><br />By Virgil Nemoianu<br />1984</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Fictions-Romantic-Harvard-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674299353"><strong><em>Fictions of Romantic Irony</em></strong> </a><br />By Lilian R. Furst<br />1984</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/THE-QUATTROCENTO-DIALOGUE-Innovation-Comparative/dp/0674741153"><strong><em>The Quattrocento Dialogue: Classical Tradition and Humanist Innovation</em></strong> </a><br />By David Marsh<br />1980</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Mirror-Translation-Imitation-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674576454"><strong><em>Mirror on Mirror: Translation, Imitation, Parody</em></strong> </a><br />By Reuben Brower<br />1974</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Comparative-Studies-Greek-Indic-Literature/dp/0674152751"><strong><em>Comparative Studies in Greek and Indic Meter</em></strong> </a><br />By Gregory Nagy<br />1974</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Grounds-Comparison-Study-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674363353"><strong><em>Grounds for Comparison</em></strong> </a><br />By Harry Levin<br />1972</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Renaissance-Discovery-Study-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674760255"><strong><em>The Renaissance Discovery of Time</em></strong> </a><br />By Ricardo J. Quinones<br />1972</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Pan-Goat-God-Modern-Comparative-Literature/dp/0674652800"><strong><em>Pan the Goat God: His Myth in Modern Times</em></strong> </a><br />By Patricia Merivale<br />1969</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Roman-Laughter-The-Comedy-Plautus/dp/0195041666"><strong><em>Roman Laughter: The Comedy of Plautus</em></strong> </a><br />By Erich Segal<br />1968</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Icelandic-family-saga-comparative/dp/B0006BOAR2"><strong><em>The Icelandic Family Saga: An Analytic Reading</em></strong> </a><br />By Theodore M. Andersson<br />1967</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Dostoevsky-Romantic-Realism-Relation-Dickens/dp/081011593X"><strong><em>Dostoevsky and Romantic Realism: A Study of Dostoevsky in Relation to Balzac, Dickens, and Gogol</em></strong> </a><br />By Donald Fanger<br />1965</p>
<p><br /><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Rogues-Progress-Studies-Picaresque-Novel/dp/B000O82GNW"><strong><em>Rogue's Progress: Studies in the Picaresque Novel</em></strong><em> </em></a><br />By Robert Alter</em> <br />1964</p>
<p><br /><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Praisers-folly-Shakespeare-comparative-literature/dp/B0006AYS3O"><strong><em>Praisers of Folly: Erasmus, Rabelais, Shakespeare</em></strong><em> </em></a><br />By Walter Kaiser</em> <br />1964</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/The-Singer-Tales-Albert-Lord/dp/0674002830"><strong><em>The Singer of Tales</em></strong> </a><br />By Albert B. Lord<br />1960</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Translation-Galaxy-Books-Reuben-Brower/dp/0195004345"><strong><em>On Translation</em></strong> </a><br />Edited by Reuben Brower<br />1959</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Contexts-Criticism-Harry-Levin/dp/B000JDUIRS"><strong><em>Contexts of Criticism</em></strong> </a><br />By Harry Levin<br />1957</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Vissarion-Belinski-1811-1848-Origins-Criticism/dp/B000O00ET8"><strong><em>Vissarion Belinski, 1811-1848</em></strong> </a><br />By Herbert E. Bowman<br />1954</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.co.uk/Perspectives-Criticism-Harvard-Comparative-Literature/dp/B0014KESLC/ref=sr_1_9/275-9586596-0605943?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1393537541&amp;sr=1-9"><strong><em>Perspectives of Criticism</em></strong> </a><br />Edited by Harry Levin<br />1950</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Testament-Werther-In-Poetry-Drama/dp/B0018JN6HG"><strong><em>The Testament of Werther in Poetry and Drama</em></strong> </a><br />By Stuart Pratt Atkins<br />1949</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Bibliography-Theophrastan-Characters-comparative-literature/dp/0837135427"><strong><em>A Bibliography of the Theophrastan Character in English with Several Portrait Characters</em></strong> </a><br />By Chester Noyes Greenough and J.M. French<br />1947</p>
<p><br /><strong><em>Un Voyageur-Philosophe au XVII Siècle: L'Abbé Jean-Bernard le Blanc</em></strong> <br />By Hélène Monod-Cassidy<br />1941</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Jean-Racine-F-B-Clark/dp/B000LY25W6/ref=sr_1_5?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1393537717&amp;sr=1-5"><strong><em>Jean Racine</em></strong> </a><br />By Alexander F.B. Clark<br />1939</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Catullus-strange-distant-Britain-Scarborough/dp/B0006CPVJM"><strong><em>Catullus in Strange and Distant Britain</em></strong> </a><br />By James A.S. McPeek<br />1939</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Proverbs-earlier-English-Bartlett-Whiting/dp/B007SZCT5Y"><strong><em>Proverbs in the Earlier English Drama</em></strong> </a><br />By Bartlett Jere Whiting<br />1938</p>
<p><br /><strong><em>D'Edmond Spenser à Alan Seeger: Poèmes Anglais Traduits en Vers Français</em></strong> <br />By Fernand Baldensperger<br />1938</p>
<p><br /><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/English-Literature-Culture-Russia-1553-1840/dp/B000IA2348"><strong><em>English Literature and Culture in Russia (1553-1840)</em></strong><em> </em></a><br />By Ernest J. Simmons</em> <br />1935</p>
<p><br /><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Chaucers-Proverbs-Bartlett-Jere-Whiting/dp/B007FMYRWS"><strong><em>Chaucer's Use of Proverbs</em></strong><em> </em></a><br />By Bartlett Jere Whiting</em> <br />1934</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Virgil-Necromancer-Studies-Virgilian-Legends/dp/0766186903"><strong><em>Virgil the Necromancer</em></strong> </a><br />By John Webster Spargo<br />1934</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/EGER-AND-GRIME-HUNTINGTON-LAING-INTRODUCTORY/dp/B000KJFGRS"><strong><em>Eger and Grime</em></strong> </a><br />By James Ralston Caldwell<br />1923</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Spenser-Table-Round-Charles-Millican/dp/0374957193"><strong><em>Spenser and the Table Round</em></strong> </a><br />By Charles Bowie Millican<br />1932</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Chaucer-Roman-Poets-Finley-Shannon/dp/B000OM3SXU"><strong><em>Chaucer and the Roman Poets</em></strong> </a><br />By Edgar Finley Shannon<br />1929</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Angevin-Britain-Scandinavia-Henry-Goddard/dp/1177575515"><strong><em>Angevin Britain and Scandinavia</em></strong> </a><br />By Henry Goddard Leach<br />1921</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Mythical-Bards-Life-William-Wallace/dp/0548205728"><strong><em>Mythical Bards and the Life of William Wallace</em></strong> </a><br />By William Henry Schofield<br />1920</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://books.google.com/books/about/Medieval_Spanish_Allegory.html?id=TT4ltwAACAAJ"><strong><em>Medieval Spanish Allegory</em></strong> </a><br />By Chandler Rathfon Post<br />1915</p>
<p><br /><strong><em><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Harvard-Studies-Comparative-Literature-Comedies/dp/B00BPUWJ94/ref=sr_1_3?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1393538040&amp;sr=1-3">The Comedies of Holberg</a> </em></strong><br />By Oscar James Campbell, Jr.<br />1914</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Chivalry-English-Literature-Shakespeare-Comparative/dp/1432552554"><strong><em>Chivalry in English Literature: Chaucer, Malory, Spenser, and Shakespeare</em></strong> </a><br />By William Henry Schofield<br />1912</p>
<p><br /><a href="http://www.amazon.com/Three-Philosophical-Poets-Lucretius-Goethe/dp/1492707341/ref=la_B001HPXQ1M_1_5?s=books&amp;ie=UTF8&amp;qid=1393533201&amp;sr=1-5"><strong><em>Three Philosophical Poets: Lucretius, Dante, and Goethe</em></strong></a><br />By George Santayana<br />1910</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/resources" >RESOURCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>

															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Library Research Guides                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-127646" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	 
</p>

<ul><li>
		<a href="http://guides.library.harvard.edu/literature" title="">Literary Research in Harvard Libraries: Comparative Edition</a>- Library resources and search strategies for comparative literature.<br /> 
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="/" title="http://guides.library.harvard.edu/litgrads">Research guide and to-do list </a><span><span><span style="color:black">for graduate students in literature</span></span></span><br /> 
	</li>
	<li>
		<a href="http://prezi.com/axm9appvtqo9/top-ten-tips/">Top Research Tips for Graduate Students</a>- A handy presentation for how to approach research. 
	</li>
</ul><p>
	 
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-42901"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/resources"  class="active-trail active">Resources</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42906"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/publications" >Publications</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-53166"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/publication-subsidies" >Schofield Publication Subsidy</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-45941"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research-guides"  class="active-trail active active">Library Research Guides</a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42911"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/visiting-scholars" >Visiting Scholars Application</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Resources                    </h1>
                </header>

  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-105801" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Please see in the side menu the various resources highlighted.</p>

      <h2 class="block-title">Follow us</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1443731628' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div class="item-list"><ul class="follow-me-links-vertical"><li><a href="https://www.facebook.com/harvardcomplit"  class="follow-icon" style="background-position: -531px 0px" target="_blank">https://www.facebook.com/harvardcomplit</a><span class='service-name-span'><a href="https://www.facebook.com/harvardcomplit"  class="follow-icon-service-name" target="_blank">Facebook</a></span></li></ul></div></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate" >UNDERGRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Secondary Field in Comparative Literature                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114681" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>General Information</h2><p>Comparative Literature offers a secondary field for students who are interested in the study of literature, literary and cultural theory, and other forms of representation in more than one culture or language. More information about the Comparative Literature secondary field can be found in the <a href="http://handbook.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-fields/book/comparative-literature" title="">Harvard College Handbook for Students.</a></p><h2>Advising Resources and Expectations</h2><p>All students interested in pursuing a secondary field in Comparative Literature should contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies, <a href="mailto:snaddaff@fas.harvard.edu">Dr. Sandra Naddaff</a> (617-495-5650) as soon as possible to discuss their program of study. Since only Comparative Literature students are allowed to enroll in Comp Lit 97, students pursuing a secondary field in Comparative Literature should contact the Director of Undergraduate Studies before the first meeting of the sophomore tutorial (in the spring semester.) The DUS will be responsible for advising these students, although the expectation will be that students working towards a secondary field in Comparative Literature will monitor their own progress towards fulfillment of the requirements.</p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-38526"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active">Undergraduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-42866"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/prospective-students" >Prospective Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56516"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/sophomores" >Sophomores</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56526"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/juniors" >Juniors</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56531"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/seniors" >Seniors</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-125981"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/tutorial-board" >Comp Lit Undergraduate Tutorial Board</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-42876"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/secondary-field-literature"  class="active-trail active active">Secondary Field in Comparative Literature</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-52311"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate-alumni" >Undergraduate Alumni</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

title="">Visiting Scholars</a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-3472 menu-path-node-92666   even  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/news-events"  title="">News</a></li><li class="menu-3814 menuparent  menu-path-node-105801   odd  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/resources"  title="">Resources</a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-4406 menu-path-node-114731  first   odd  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/publications" >Publications</a></li><li class="menu-12979 menu-path-complitfasharvardedu-publication-subsidies   </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate" >GRADUATE</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Teaching                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-140941" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2>
	Teaching Fellow Handbooks
</h2>

<p>
	<br />Both the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences and the Department of Comparative Literature have created handbooks for graduate student teaching fellows.  These handbooks provide information, tips, and strategies regarding successful teaching and tutoring practices for department students—especially those at the beginning of their teaching careers.
</p>

<p>
	Please find below the Comp Lit Teaching Fellow Handbook.<br />You are also encourage to review the following GSAS guidelines: <a href="http://www.gsas.harvard.edu/current_students/the_tf_role_expectations_responsibilities_and_conduct.php">The TF Role: Expectations, Responsibilities, and Conduct.</a>
</p>

<p>
	International Students interested in teaching at other U.S. universities while enrolled at GSAS should read <a href="http://complit.fas.harvard.edu/files/complit/files/optandcpt.pdf?m=1446476102">this document</a> concerning Optional Practical Training (OPT) or Curricular Practical Training (CPT).
</p>

<p>
	 
</p>

<p>
	 
</p>
</div></div></div><table class="os-files-other-list">
<tbody>
 <tr class="odd"><td class="mime mime-pdf"><img class="file-icon" alt="" src="/profiles/openscholar/modules/os/modules/os_files/icons/application-pdf.svg" /></td><td class="file"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/files/complit/files/teaching_fellow_handbook_-_2016-17_final_7_26_16.pdf" >teaching_fellow_handbook_-_2016-17_final_7_26_16.pdf</a></td><td class="size">361 KB</td> </tr>
</tbody>
</table>
  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-38531"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/graduate"  class="active-trail active">Graduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42881"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/admissions" >Admissions</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42891"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/forms-and-resources" >Forms and Resources</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-131331"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/journalsconferences-graduate-students" >Journals/Conferences for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42886"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/guide-graduate-students" >Guide for Graduate Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-45931"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/phd-dissertations" >PhD Dissertations</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42896"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/poggioli-colloquium" >Poggioli Faculty/Student Colloquium</a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-48421"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/teaching"  class="active-trail active active">Teaching</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-106121"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/graduate-alumni" >Graduate Alumni</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-108431"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/alumni-connect" >Alumni Directory </a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-146616"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-field-comparative-literature" >Secondary Field in Comparative Literature</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">  
  
  <ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-primary-menu" id="nice-menu-primary-menu"><li class="menu-3470 menu-path-front  first   odd  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/"   </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Undergraduate                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-92676" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h2 class="p1">Welcome from the Director of Undergraduate Studies<br /> </h2><p><img height="200" width="300" style="float: left;" alt="Sandra Naddaff" title="Sandra Naddaff" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/complit/files/111213_naddaff_sandra_128_605.jpg?m=1386622341&amp;itok=oyeGr2Mw" />The undergraduate concentration in Comparative Literature offers students the opportunity to design a program of study that works across languages, cultures, and media in a comparative and interdisciplinary context. The open, flexible nature of the concentration allows students to develop an individualized program of study that incorporates literary and cultural analysis in the exploration of any number of fields and disciplines both within and beyond the Humanities. Some students, for example, develop a curriculum in Literature and the Arts, linking the study of literature with film, music, theater, digital media, or creative writing.  Others design programs that connect literary study to contemporary concerns and disciplines beyond the Humanities, focusing their work on the relationship between Literature and Medicine, for example, or Literature and Law, or Literature and Ethics.  Still other students find in the study of Comparative Literature a place for the comparative study of multiple literatures, World Literature, and translation, or the examination of aesthetics, philosophy, and literary and cultural theory. In short, the undergraduate program in Comparative Literature provides an ideal home for students who wish to craft a comparative and interdisciplinary concentration that is embedded in the Humanities but has the potential to reach beyond.</p><p>Given the comparative nature of our program, the knowledge of more than one language and national literature is essential.  Our students work in a multitude of languages—Hindi, French, Spanish, Chinese, Hebrew, Italian, Latin, Arabic, Swahili—to name but a few.  We welcome work in any language in which a student has interest and is able to take minimally 3 courses in which they work in the original language.  In cases where a student does not have the necessary linguistic competence to undertake literary study, we are happy to help make arrangements to acquire the necessary proficiency through continued course work or summer study. </p><p class="p1">Students with degrees in Comparative Literature develop habits of mind that serve them well in any number of professional endeavors.  The ability to write well, to read critically, to argue analytically, and to speak eloquently, translates fluently to a variety of fields. Alumni have gone on to careers in a wide variety of fields, including academics, journalism, film, law, medicine, and business. Notable Lit alumni include A.O. Scott (1988), film critic for <em>The New York Times</em>; Kelefa Sanneh (1997), staff writer for <em>The New Yorker</em>; Elif Batuman (1999), author of <em>The Possessed: Adventures with Russian Books and the People Who Read Them</em>; Alexandra McCormack (2000), corporate lawyer with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher &amp; Flom in New York; B.J. Novak (2001), Actor (<em>The Office, Inglorious Basterds</em>); Rasheed Sabar (2005), portfolio manager for the Ellington Management Group hedge fund; and Cara Eisenpress (2007), cookbook author (In the Small Kitchen: 100 Recipes from Our Year of Cooking in the Real World). </p><p class="p1" style="text-align:right">- <em>Sandra Naddaff</em></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-38526"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/undergraduate"  class="active-trail active active">Undergraduate</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-42866"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/prospective-students" >Prospective Students</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56516"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/sophomores" >Sophomores</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56526"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/juniors" >Juniors</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-56531"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/seniors" >Seniors</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-125981"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/tutorial-board" >Comp Lit Undergraduate Tutorial Board</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42876"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/secondary-field-literature" >Secondary Field in Comparative Literature</a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-52311"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/undergraduate-alumni" >Undergraduate Alumni</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->
        
				
			</div>
		</div>

<meta name="description" content="The Department of Comparative Literature each year welcomes a limited number of qualified visitors whose academic interests intersect directly with the teaching and research activities of the department&#039;s faculty members. Because the department’s faculty members and students thrive on intellectual engagement with guest researchers, visitors are encouraged to participate actively in the life of the department and the university, attending lectures, conferences, film showings, and classes with permission of the instructor." />
<meta property="og:description" content="The Department of Comparative Literature each year welcomes a limited number of qualified visitors whose academic interests intersect directly with the teaching and research activities of the department&#039;s faculty members. Because the department’s faculty members and students thrive on intellectual engagement with guest researchers, visitors are encouraged to participate actively in the life of the department and the university, attending lectures, conferences, film showings, and classes with permission of the instructor." />

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/resources" >RESOURCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Visiting Scholars Application                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-114746" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The Department of Comparative Literature each year welcomes a limited number of qualified visitors whose academic interests intersect directly with the teaching and research activities of the department's faculty members. Because the department’s faculty members and students thrive on intellectual engagement with guest researchers, visitors are encouraged to participate actively in the life of the department and the university, attending lectures, conferences, film showings, and classes with permission of the instructor. Visitors may be invited to present an informal talk or seminar during the course of their stay.  English language proficiency is assumed, and will be verified by the faculty host.<br /><br />Although these visiting appointments carry no financial support of any kind, visitors are given a Harvard e-mail address and a Harvard identification card, which gives them access to Harvard College libraries and museums. The University provides assistance with the visa process for scholars coming from outside the United States. Visitors are entirely responsible for obtaining their own funding, for making their own travel and living arrangements, and for obtaining health insurance. The Department is unable to provide office space or supplies.<br />The Department of Comparative Literature hosts three types of visitors:<br /><br /><strong>1.    Visiting Scholar</strong>: doctorate not required, but usually in hand.  The Visiting Scholar appointment enables individuals, ordinarily ladder faculty members on paid leave from another institution (tenured or tenure-track), to carry out their own work in association with a Harvard faculty member.<br /><br /><strong>2.    Fellow:</strong> for individuals who have recently received the Ph.D. or are currently in the final years of a Ph.D. program.  The Fellow appointment allows advanced graduate students and Ph.D.'s in the early years of their scholarly careers opportunities for individual research under the guidance of a department faculty member.<br /><br /><strong>3.    Associates:</strong> generally for alumni of the department or other individuals with a need for department affiliation.  For more on the Associate program, please contact the department.  <br /><br />The department gives preference for appointments of 12 months’ duration; with rare exception, Visiting Scholars are not accepted for less than 6 months, and the absolute minimum is three months. Extensions to the initial appointment are granted only very rarely.</p><p><strong>How to Apply</strong><br />Acceptance as a visitor is competitive; the department can accommodate only a handful of individuals at any one time.  Applications should include the following (all materials must be in English):<br /><br />1.    current curriculum vitae<br />2.    brief description (1-2 pages) of research project<br />3.    cover letter specifying the desired dates of appointment<br />4.    brief letter from the Comparative Literature faculty member who has agreed to sponsor the visit<br /><br />Please note, the department has recently changed its application procedures.  <br /><br />Applications for the academic year 2018-2019 are due <span style="text-decoration:underline"><strong>January 15, 2018</strong></span>, for review first by the department’s Visiting Scholars Committee and then by the full department at its February 2018 department meeting.  The department is aware that many fellowship applications require a formal letter of invitation, but the department cannot make exceptions to the above dates and urges potential visiting scholars/fellows to plan accordingly.<br /><br />Applications should be sent by email to Melissa Carden, Department Administrator (<a href="mailto:carden@fas.harvard.edu">carden@fas.harvard.edu</a>).  The department’s mailing address is 16 Quincy Street, Dana-Palmer House, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA 02138, USA.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-42901"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/resources"  class="active-trail active">Resources</a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-42906"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/publications" >Publications</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-53166"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/publication-subsidies" >Schofield Publication Subsidy</a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-45941"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/research-guides" >Library Research Guides</a></li><li class="last leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-42911"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/pages/visiting-scholars"  class="active-trail active active">Visiting Scholars Application</a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

<article id="node-913466" class="node node-person article with-person-photo modified-in-os_profiles_process_node clearfix" role="article" target="_top">

      <div class="field field-name-field-person-photo field-type-imagefield-crop field-label-hidden view-mode-sidebar_teaser">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item even">
      <figure>
        <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/yao-mengze"  target="_top"><img class="image-style-profile-thumbnail" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/profile_thumbnail/public/complit/files/yao_mengze.jpg?m=1501772871&amp;itok=dnFGGZdi" width="75" height="75" alt="Yao Mengze" title="Yao Mengze" /></a>              </figure>
      </div>
        </div>
</div>  
      
      
    <div class="node-content">
      <h1  class="node-title" rel="nofollow"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/yao-mengze" target="_top">Yao Mengze</a></h1><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-sidebar_teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Visiting Scholar 2016/2017</div><div class="field-item odd"> </div></div></div>    </div>
  
      
      
      </article>

					<!--header regions beg-->

			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1443549664" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1443549664"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1443549664' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-522611" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/files/complit/files/banner_department_of_comparative_literature.jpg?m=1508249831">banner_department_of_comparative_literature.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/complit/files/banner_department_of_comparative_literature.jpg?m=1499733535&amp;itok=hgFFPlFb" width="980" height="170" alt="" title="" />  </div>

				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">  
  
  <ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-primary-menu" id="nice-menu-primary-menu"><li class="menu-3470 menu-path-front  first   odd  "><a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/" 																					<h1 id="page-title">
												Graduate Students											</h1>
																													</header>
																
																	<div id="content">
										<div class="view view-os-profiles view-id-os_profiles view-display-id-page view-dom-id-2d52c710b1a8cd3e7ca8a989d33d586d">
        
  
  
      <div class="view-content">
        <div class="views-row views-row-1 views-row-odd views-row-first">

    <div class="field field-name-field-person-photo field-type-imagefield-crop field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser">

        <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/lindsey-aakre" ><img class="image-style-profile-thumbnail" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/profile_thumbnail/public/complit/files/lindsey.png?m=1500388288&amp;itok=z3v1hHVI" width="75" height="75" alt="Aakre" title="Aakre" /></a>              </figure>

    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">  
              <header class="node-header">
                      <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/lindsey-aakre" rel="bookmark">Lindsey Aakre</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student<br /> </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<strong>Research Fields: </strong>Comparative poetics, Classical Chinese poetry, early modern lyric consciousness, folk and fairy tales, "World Literature" and the humanities. My dissertation is on eleventh-century Chinese poets and the practice of poetic modeling. <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/lindsey-aakre" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Lindsey Aakre</span></a></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:laakre@fas.harvard.edu" >laakre@fas.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>
    
          
          
          </div>
    
  </article>
  </div>

      <div class="node-content">

      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student: Graduating November 2017<br /> </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<strong>Research Fields: </strong><span>Film history and theory, the political avant-garde in Japan, France, and the former USSR, graphic narratives and comics, animation, philosophy, ethics, feminism, Marxism. <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/julia-alekseyeva" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Julia Alekseyeva</span></a></span></p></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-website field-type-link-field field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="http://www.jalekseyeva.com/"  title="Julia Alekseyeva&#039;s website">Personal Website</a><br /></div><div class="field-item odd"><a href="https://microcosmpublishing.com/catalog/books/6320"  title="Julia Alekseyeva&#039;s website">Book: Soviet Daughter</a><br /></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:aleksey@fas.harvard.edu" >aleksey@fas.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>

    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">  
              <header class="node-header">
                      <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/nina-begus" rel="bookmark">Nina Begus</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<strong>Research Fields:</strong> Modernist fiction (anglophone, francophone, Austrian, Balkan); the Habsburg myth; ancient Greece; world literature; narrative theory; music; film; artificial life, human vs. non-human; medical humanities, science writing; islands and utopias; Pacific literature; Tocharian, Sanskrit, and Chinese tales of the Silk Road. <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/nina-begus" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Nina Begus</span></a></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:nbegus@fas.harvard.edu" >nbegus@fas.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>

    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">  
              <header class="node-header">
                      <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/daniel-behar" rel="bookmark">Daniel Behar</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student <br />Tutorial Board Teaching Fellow<br /> </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<strong>Research Fields: </strong>Comparative Modernisms, Modern and Classical Arabic Literature, Modern Hebrew Literature, Hebrew Bible, 20<sup>th</sup> Century Anglo-American and European Poetry &amp; Fiction.
</p>

<p class="DefaultText">
	<span style="font-size:13px; font-family:arial,sans,sans-serif; color:#000000; text-align:left"> <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/daniel-behar" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Daniel Behar</span></a></span></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:dbehar@fas.harvard.edu" >dbehar@fas.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>

    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">  
              <header class="node-header">
                      <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/francesca-bellei" rel="bookmark">Francesca Bellei</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student<br />  </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>Research Fields: </strong>Migration and diaspora studies; postcolonial literature (mostly Anglophone &amp; Francophone) and theory; women and gender studies; bilingualism; sociolinguistics; questions of identity and nationhood, particularly Mediterranean; Latin and Ancient Greek literature and philosophy, Italian literature, contemporary fiction and creative writing. <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/francesca-bellei" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Francesca Bellei</span></a></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:bellei@g.harvard.edu" >bellei@g.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>

    <article id="node-866971" class="node node-person node-teaser article with-person-photo modified-in-os_profiles_process_node clearfix" role="article">

      
    
    <div class="field field-name-field-person-photo field-type-imagefield-crop field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item even">
      <figure>
        <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/aurelien-bellucci" ><img class="image-style-profile-thumbnail" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/profile_thumbnail/public/complit/files/aurelien_bellucci.jpg?m=1475091911&amp;itok=u1SP0HQL" width="75" height="75" alt="Aurélien Bellucci" title="Aurélien Bellucci" /></a>              </figure>
      </div>
        </div>
</div>    
    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">  
              <header class="node-header">
                      <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/aurelien-bellucci" rel="bookmark">Aurélien Bellucci</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student<br /> </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div><strong>Research Fields: </strong>Aesthetics and Politics, Modern and Contemporary Fiction, Theatre and Performance Studies, Translation Theory <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/aurelien-bellucci" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Aurélien Bellucci</span></a></div></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:  abellucci@g.harvard.edu" >  abellucci@g.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>
    
          
          
          </div>
    
  </article>
  </div>
  <div class="views-row views-row-9 views-row-odd">
    <article id="node-649466" class="node node-person node-teaser article with-person-photo modified-in-os_profiles_process_node clearfix" role="article">

    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">

              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/cecily-cai" rel="bookmark">Cecily Cai</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student<br /> </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>
	<strong>Research Fields:</strong> 19th- and 20th-century European literature; literary criticism; aesthetics; poetry in translation; performing arts
</p>

<p>
	 <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/cecily-cai" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Cecily Cai</span></a></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:siyucai@g.harvard.edu" >siyucai@g.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>

  </article>

    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">

              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/fangdai-chen" rel="bookmark">Fangdai Chen</a>

                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student<br /> </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span><strong>Research Fields:</strong> English, French, German and Chinese literatures since the late 19th century, modernism and postmodernism, poetry and poetics, philosophy of language (Derrida, Wittgenstein), literary theory, European and East Asian intellectual history, politics and literature, translation studies </span></p><p><span></span></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:fangdai_chen@g.harvard.edu" >fangdai_chen@g.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>

      <div class="node-content">

    <article id="node-144871" class="node node-person node-teaser article with-person-photo modified-in-os_profiles_process_node clearfix" role="article">

      
    
    <div class="field field-name-field-person-photo field-type-imagefield-crop field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser">
    <div class="field-items">
            <div class="field-item even">
      <figure>
        <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/aisha-dad-van-veldhuizen" ><img class="image-style-profile-thumbnail" src="//static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/profile_thumbnail/public/complit/files/aisha.jpg?m=1494515538&amp;itok=p3R1g8l5" width="75" height="75" alt="Aisha Dad-Van Veldhuizen" title="Aisha Dad-Van Veldhuizen" /></a>              </figure>
      </div>
        </div>
</div>    
    <div class="person-teaser-wrapper">  
              <header class="node-header">
                      <h1 class="node-title" rel="nofollow">
              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/aisha-dad-van-veldhuizen" rel="bookmark">Aisha Dad-Van Veldhuizen</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="DefaultText">
	<strong>Research Fields:</strong> Greek, Persian and Latin literature; Greek epic and tragedy; Persian epic; Latin epic; Urdu folklore and <em>Dastan </em>literature; oral poetics; performance studies; ancient Greek music; mythology; history and legend of Alexander the Great; themes: travel, kinship, heroes; allegory; Arthurian legend; medieval, renaissance and pre-modern epic (Dante, Milton, <em>Tale of Genji</em>); 19<sup>th</sup>-(20<sup>th</sup>) century American literature (Poe, Faulkner, Twain); magical realism; postmodernism.
</p>

<p>
	 <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/aisha-dad-van-veldhuizen" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Aisha Dad-Van Veldhuizen</span></a></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:aishadad@fas.harvard.edu" >aishadad@fas.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>
    
          
          
          </div>
    
  </article>
  </div>

              <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/matylda-figlerowicz" rel="bookmark">Matylda Figlerowicz</a>
            </h1>
                  </header>
        
      <div class="node-content">
        <div class="pic-bio clearfix"><div class="field field-name-field-professional-title field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even">Graduate Student <br />Tutorial Board Teaching Fellow<br /> </div></div></div><div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>Research Fields:</strong><strong> </strong>Affect theory, biopolitics, memory studies, queer theory; questions of bilingualism, exile, displacements, Otherness, and cosmopolitism; 20<sup>th</sup>/21<sup>st</sup> century literatures of Spain and Latin America (in different languages spoken there); art history and visual studies (especially performance and body art). <a href="https://complit.fas.harvard.edu/people/matylda-figlerowicz" class="node-readmore">Read more <span class="element-invisible"> about Matylda Figlerowicz</span></a></p></div></div></div></div><div class="field field-name-field-email field-type-text field-label-hidden view-mode-teaser"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><a href="mailto:matyldafiglerowicz@g.harvard.edu" >matyldafiglerowicz@g.harvard.edu</a></div></div></div>      </div>
